dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darkness. The faint background hum of a refrigerator. A l clicks on, briefly, then snaps off again. Then on again, for a little longer. We wake groggily with JACK (five), blinking up at MA (26) She's standing in a worn t-shirt and underwear beside a l switching it on and off at apparently random intervals. S cranes up at the recessed skylight, Room's only window. The irregular flashes of lamp-light reveal glimpses of th little world lined with cork: ten foot a side, seven foot high, gabled ceiling rising to ten foot. Clusters of Jack's and Ma's vivid drawings are pinned all over the walls, quivering in the draft from the vents. Do with five crayons (red, yellow, blue, orange, green) and pencil on toilet tissue, lined pages or cardboard, they s dogs, trees, aliens, rocket ships, figures labelled 'Jack 'Ma'. Delicate mobiles (uncooked spaghetti, threads, plastics, foil, down from pillows, cloth scraps) dangle. A wardrobe with slatted louver doors. On top, toys crafte from garbage, a Labyrinth from toilet-roll insides. A dresser with a TV. A homemade pack of cards, papier mГў checkers and chess. A Fort constructed from vitamin and o bottles and cans. A single meagre African violet in a pot the TV. A round dining table, two fold-up chairs side by side. A bath with a single small towel over the side. A toilet, with a flotilla of homemade toy boats floating the tank which is oddly missing a lid. A sink, with a single worn toothbrush, toothpaste, dish s a broken comb, folded rags for washcloths. A small square mirror tile hung up over it. A small kitchen cabinet. A dish rack: two each of big and small white plates, bowls, tumblers, knives, forks, spoon (one with a melted handle), a scissors, can opener, serra knife, wooden spoon, spatula. A basic stove (with more folded rags on its handle, for p holders), one frying pan and one saucepan. A small refrigerator (more toys on top), a tiny trash.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: A rocker.    Above, a shelf. Ten books stacked. Homemade A reddish Persian-style rug on the floor. A grey steel door, no handle. On the wall, a ten-digit keypad with a red light like a watching eye. Ma looks over at Jack and sees that he's awake. She mouth 'Sh' at him, soothing him back to sleep. Keeps signalling Darkness again, as Jack's eyelids fall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Faint light. Jack and Ma sleep face to face in a double b under a thin quilt. Pale skin, long hair, wearing t-shirt

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You cried all day and left TV on till you were a zombie. But then I zoomed down from heaven through Skylight into Room - (makes noise of descent, then crash landing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: and I was kicking you from the inside, boom boom, and then I shot out onto Rug with my eyes wide open, and you cutted the cord and said "Hello Jack." Jack wakes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ma. I'm five!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A little later, Ma, at the kitchen counter, measures out small bowls of cereal. Jack moves round Room touching things: Rug's rusty bloods from his birth; the scarred Table; chairs; faucets, etc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morning lamp, Morning rug, Morning wardrobe .. (he looks under the bed)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: JACK (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morning Eggsnake. It's my birthday. I'm five.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Ma puts breakfast on the table. Sits. Jack sits, too. Ma gives him a half vitamin pill from an almost empty tub. She takes a contraceptive pill from a generic pack. They start to eat. Ma winces. JACK (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is Bad Tooth hurting? MA (taps her head)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mind over matter. He taps his head too as he chants the slogan. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If we don't mind, it doesn't matter. MA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guess what we're going to make later. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? MA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A cake. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A birthday cake, like in TV? MA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But for real.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A little later, Ma is brushing Jack's teeth (with their single, frayed brush) zealously. He spits with vigor. A little later, Ma and Jack are looking a two small piles clothes. MA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on slow poke. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You, pink soft, pink swirls. MA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You always pick that. But I guess it's your birthday.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She reaches for her clothes. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me, bear and jeans. MA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good choice! A little later. Ma scrubs the floor with an old cloth dia while Jack watches TV. Both in t-shirt and jeans (Jack's worn-out knees), but shoeless. DORA THE EXPLORER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We couldn't have done it without you. Thanks for helping. Gracias. The salsa theme tune starts. MA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Off, please. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just one more planet. Ma stands up, doing a zombie impression. MA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Too much TV will turn us into zombies ... Anyway, it's time to mark how tall you are. This makes him switch the TV off fast and run to the door Ma marks his height with a tiny 5 in black pen on the cor Jack ducks and uses his fingers to measure the gap. Frown JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not very taller after four. MA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, that's pretty normal. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah? MA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything's hunky-dory. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okey-dokey. He touches the space between 3 (in red) and 4 (in black).

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: JACK (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's where Red Pen died and we got Black Pen for Sunday Treat. Hey, what about cookies? MA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, I already asked for jeans for you for Sunday Treat. He swallows his disappointment. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to grow and grow till I'm a giant. Look, Ma. Look how big my superpowers are already. He makes a tiny bicep. Ma musters enthusiasm at the prosp of him growing up. MA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll be as strong as Samson soon. JACK (holding up his long hair)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huger every day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gigantic. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enormous. Hugeormous. MA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good word sandwich. He starts leaping around the room, moving gracefully betw all the familiar obstacles. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to be Jack the Giant Giant-Killer and burst out of Skylight into Space with my dog Lucky and boing boing boing between all the planets...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A little later, playing 'Track'. The rug is draped over t table on the bed. They run back and forward on a worn C, of them training hard, like athletes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Later, the furniture is back in place. Jack picks Dylan t Digger from his stack, which includes Pop-Up Airport, My Book of Nursery Rhymes, The Runaway Bunny, Alice in Wonderland. (He ignores the adult books - The Da Vinci Co Twilight, The Guardian, Bittersweet Love, The Shack.) Ma can't hide her revulsion at Dylan the Digger again. MA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, you can read Dylan yourself. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can read them all but I like when you do. Ma recites animatedly. Jack turns the board pages, not noticing that Ma's eyes are shut as she reads from memory MA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Heeeeeeeere's Dylan, the sturdy digger! / The loads he shovels get bigger and bigger. / Watch his long arm delve into the earth, / No excavator so loves to munch dirt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Later, Jack blows the second of two small eggs, keeping t shell intact. Beating butter and sugar, Ma keeps up their Rhyme game. MA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our friend Table... just isn't able. Jack pours the eggs into her bowl of butter and sugar. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our friend Spoon, sings to the moon. Ma beats the eggs in. MA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our friend Knife runs for his life. She winces in pain, and shakes out her right wrist. Jack notices and takes over, beating the batter for her.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Later: Ma strings the shells onto the needle tongue of th Eggsnake, made of eggshells crayoned, given paper clothes foil crowns, colored wool for hair... Eggsnake is hundred of eggs long.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A little later. The birthday cake is small, brown, plain. Ma makes a 5 with thin white icing. MA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Abracadabra! JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now the candles. Reading her face, his crumples. JACK (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You said a birthday cake for real. That means candles on fire. MA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack - JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should ask for candles for Sunday Treat, not dumb jeans. MA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry. I have to ask for stuff we really need that he can get easily. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Old Nick gets anything, by magic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Try your cake, I bet it's delicioso. But Jack is sulking. She hugs him, quietly soothing him. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Next week when I'm six you better ask for real candles. MA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Next year, you mean. Later: Half the cake is eaten.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Jack is kneeling at the bath. There's a bucket with dishe front of him. He's washing up as expertly as an adult.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Later. Steam makes Room mysterious. Jack lies on Ma in th bath, both with bubble moustaches. End of the Selkie stor

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But one day the mermaid finds where the fisherman hid her comb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ha ha.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So she runs home to the sea. She lets her head and face sink under the water. Jack sits up on her, upset. Ma emerges and opens her eyes.   Realizes what's wrong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course she takes her Baby Jack with her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does he drown?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, he's half-merman. He can breathe air or water, whichever. Satisfied, Jack leans over to scoop up the pile of clothe

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laundry Time. With relish, he plunges them under the water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laundry is hung up to dry everywhere. Ma and Jack are in their sleep t-shirts and underwear. She sits breastfeedin him and telling him a story.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... and Edmond swims and swims to the island of Monte Cristo and digs up all the treasure, and ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A little later Jack watches as Ma places blankets and a pillow on the floor of the wardrobe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can we have more birthday cake?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just a bite.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've brushed our teeth already.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One more story? She checks her watch nervously: getting close to nine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack, it's late. Come on. Jack jumps in and snuggles down. Pictures of Dora and her monkey Boots are glued on the back wall; this is a tiny r within Room. Ma covers him up for the night. She begins to sing `The Big Rock Candy Mountain'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A little later. Dim light comes through the slats. Jack l stroking the dangling clothes, the pictures glued to the wardrobe. He freezes at the sound of the beeps that mean outside door is about to open. He lies absolutely still, listening for Old Nick's entran He savors the scent of fresh air, but shivers: winter. Boom: now the door's shut again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey. Jack goes up on his elbow to squint through the slats but only sees a bit of the man's down jacket as he takes it o

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here's the jeans.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The grapes were way too much, so I got canned pears. Jack can see Ma as she puts groceries away.

dialogues.speaker: OK.
dialogues.text: Now OLD NICK moves into view too. Forties, solidly built, blue-collar: a ordinary monster.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that? A birthday cake? He cuts himself a piece and eats it in a few bites. Ma starts getting undressed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shoulda told me, I'd have brought him a present. Jack twitches at this thrilling possibility. Old Nick starts undressing too: like some dull marriage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's he now, four? Jack, in the wardrobe, is all agog for Ma to correct him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (too low to be heard)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Five. Sounds of the adults getting into bed. The lamp clicking Then the familiar creaks of the bed. Jack doesn't know wh they mean but is troubled. He counts them under his breat

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One, two, three, four...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's Room, then Outer Space, then Heaven. Plant is real but not trees. Spiders are real and one time the mosquito that was sucking my blood. But squirrels and dogs are just TV, except Lucky my dog that might be some day. Mountains are too big to be real and the sea. In the dark of the wardrobe, Jack is still counting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One twenty-eight, one twenty- nine...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TV persons are flat and made of colors with red mouths and clothes instead of skin but me and you are real. Old Nick I don't know if he's real, maybe half? Green beans are real and chocolate but not ice cream. The bedsprings are speeding up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three hundred six, seven, eight - A primal grunt from Old Nick. The creaking is done. Jack asleep at the bottom of the wardrobe. Old Nick goes over to the TV and switches on sports.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shh. He turns down the volume. The sound of the sports broadca overlaps with the thud of the door closing. The wardrobe opens admitting the faint light of the L.E.D on the keypa We cut to a shot of Ma putting a sleeping Jack into the b As she starts to climb in beside we pull back and crane u

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Next morning. Jack watches a nature programme on TV: time lapse photography of one glorious tree.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Ma is using a needle and thread to take in Jack's new, mu too-big jeans. Jack finds a trodden cigarette butt under corner of the rug. Old Nick must have brought it in on hi shoe. Jack studies it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fallen leaves decompose and return nutrients to the soil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to herself, referring to the jeans)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cheap piece of ... Jack looks at the sad African violet on the bedside table

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why Plant doesn't make flowers anymore?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe she's tired.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack, on the bed: he squirms, twists, bounces with intens boyish energy. Beside the bed now, he runs on the spot at maximum speed. the background we see Ma cooking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Later the same day. Ma is napping. Jack is playing on the floor. Counting things. Tracing the patterns of rug with finger. What was that? He stares at the floor by the stove; glimp something. Jack tiptoes over, but the moving thing is gone. He looks furtively at Ma then takes out the cake. He crumbles some sets the plate on the floor. He squats and waits. A mouse puts its nose out, sniffs and takes a crumb. Something smashes into the stove: one of Ma's heavy books Jack cries out in shock and distress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You made him gone! Ma starts to sweep up the crumbs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was an alive thing, he was real!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They'd steal our food. She crawls under the counter, finds the hole. Tears alumi foil from the roll. Scrunches it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mouse can have my food, I'm not hungry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They'd bring in germs, bite us in the night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mouse is my friend and you splatted him dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No I didn't, he's hunky-dory. She stops blocking up the hole to hug Jack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you just tricking me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I swear, he's safe at home with his Ma in the backyard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What backyard? Ma, realizing her slip, tidies up instead of answering.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mouse lives in a yard in TV? Ma holds up the aluminum foil to distract him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, let's make a UFO with this. Jack brings out the other grudge he's been nursing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why you didn't tell Old Nick it was my birthday?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because he's not our friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He said he'd brung me a present.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You shouldn't hear what he - You're meant to be asleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never had a present.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He didn't mean it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It might be Lucky my dog.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack. We can't have a dog. We don't have room - (sees him misunderstand)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - space, enough space - cooped up in here with the barking, the scratching...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucky won't scratch, he promises.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is no Lucky!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah there is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's just made-up, in your head, he's not real. Devastated, Jack bursts into tears. Ma sits down beside him and strokes him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That evening. Jack sits in Ma's lap, watching a TALK-SHOW hostess interview a one-armed war veteran. Ma is threadin eggshells onto a string, hundreds of shells long. Jack ge supports the unraveled part. Ma lets out a big yawn and discreetly rubs her aching jaw

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...most poignant aspect, I can speak for all our viewers, so, so deeply moved by what you endured.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ma. Where are we when we're asleep?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right here in Room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But dreams. Do we go into TV for dreaming?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're never anywhere but here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want some. They put down Eggsnake and Ma turns to him so he can breastfeed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ma lies on the bed. Jack is nowhere to be seen. Eventuall his voice comes from the wardrobe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ma! I think Old Nick lives in TV, like Mouse. That's where he goes when he's not here in Room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack. Go to sleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The third morning. Jack wakes up in the bed, where Ma alw carries him once Old Nick has gone. Ma is up already, sitting at the table, staring at a shin red truck and remote in a hard pack. The snake is in Eden Jack can hardly believe what's in front of him. He looks it for a while.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can open it. We watch as Jack opens the box. Ma tries to help him when finds the packaging difficult.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pulling it away from her)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can do it. Later, Jack is playing with his new toy. Ma watches him uneasily. We hear a faint echo of screaming ... CHAPTER TITLE: UNLYING The screaming get's louder. Later, Ma is standing on a chair screaming and howling at Skylight. Jack stands in the bath screaming into the smal air vent above the shelf. He holds his truck up to the ve so it can join in. Then they hush and listen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why the aliens never scream back?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess they still can't hear us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tomorrow we'll do even louderer. Later, Ma, preoccupied, trims mold off cheese she slices thin and lays on brown bread. Puts it in the toaster oven Jack zigzags his truck around chair and table legs. Ma ch to see if the frozen peas are boiling yet. Jack drives th truck at the door: clang.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What smells bad? Ma belatedly realizes the grilled cheese is smoking. She burns her hand slightly on the oven, wrenching it ope

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That evening. Jack, in the wardrobe, is meant to be aslee but he's still playing with his truck. The door beeps; he kneels up for a glimpse as it booms sh

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey. What's the smell? He puts down groceries, unzips his jacket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, I burned some cheese.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You need to take more care.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will. I wasn't thinking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, well, thinking's not your strong suit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. I'm really sorry. Ma is unpacking the groceries.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So did he like his truck? He laughs at her speechless discomfort.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know boys, I was one once. Ma looks at the empty bag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The vitamins?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Waste of money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If we had a better diet, maybe...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here we go again. You know instead of complaining maybe you should thank your lucky stars you've got a place like this. Cosy, safe, specially with the kid - no drunk drivers, drug-pushers, perverts...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like pulling teeth sometimes. Ma waits for him to calm down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your problem is you have no idea about the world of today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who pays the power bills? Who pays for everything? She gives the required answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And where do you think the money's going to keep coming from?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, but -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Six months I've been laid off, have you had to worry your little head? Pause as Ma takes in the implications of this. She procee cautiously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you going to do? He doesn't answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you... looking for another job?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What job? There are no damn jobs, Jesus Christ! Jack, frightened, shrinks back in the wardrobe knocking i the back panel. Old Nick turns his attention to the wardr

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey in there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's asleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't think so. You keep him in the closet all day as well as all night? Poor little freak has two heads or something? He roots in his jacket pockets and produces an already op tube of hard candy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey Jack. You like candy? Wanna come out and have some candy? Jack, tempted, reaches for the door... Desperate to distract Old Nick, Ma touches his arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's go to bed. Old Nick chuckles at this unaccustomed seductiveness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Didn't your Momma ever teach you manners?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Pocketing the candy, he wraps himself round her. They edge backwards out of view. The lamp snaps off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A little later, everything is quiet.   Moonlight. Jack, asleep in a crooked position, wakes with a jump. He sits up and rubs his neck. Finds his truck. He opens the and peeks out. Where's the candy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stepping out, holding his truck for moral support, Jack stumbles into something and gasps. He picks it up: a thic leather belt, like a cobra.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He takes another few steps and stubs his toe on a huge bo Jack stares at Old Nick, asleep in the middle of the bed. Ma is sleeping too, clinging to the far side. Now he's come this far, Jack forgets the candy, fascinate Old Nick, whom he's seeing up close for the first time. Jack puts his finger out, almost touching Old Nick's face Old Nick's eyes open, startled.   Then he grins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey sonny. Ma leaps up screaming and flailing at Old Nick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get away from him! Get away! Jack drops his truck and races to the wardrobe. He jumps in and pulls the door, banging his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack clutches his head, curled up in the corner of the wardrobe, because it hurts, and to shut out Ma's screechi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop that noise. Ma is suddenly muted. The thump of Old Nick throwing her on the bed. The lamp snaps on. Jack flinches and turns hi face away from the light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of all the crazy... Sound of him pulling his clothes on, kicking the truck aw

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hoarsely)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just leave him alone. The door makes the three beeps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just don't forget where you got him.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Sound of the door opening, then shutting with a boom. Jac waits to hear what Ma will do or say to him. The lamp clicks off again: darkness. Jack dives out of th wardrobe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry I - sorry - sorry - He sobs and hyperventilates by the side of the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry I came out of Wardrobe. Ma takes him into bed with her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's OK. She soothes him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shot of ice-crystals on the skylight. Silence: no refrigerator hum. Jack wakes first, shivering, though he doesn't know why. is astonished by purple bruises around Ma's throat. As if feels his gaze, Ma wakes and musters a smile. Jack notice the white clouds of their breath in the air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ma, we're dragons. Ma sits up. Registers the chill. Getting out of bed, she turns on the lamp: no light. Jack is crushed to finds his Jeep, one wheel snapped off. Ma opens the refrigerator: dark inside. She's appalled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's cut the power. She glances at the keypad: its little red light is out. With a wild, illogical hope, she hurls herself at the doo and claws at its edges - but it's still locked. Jack watc bewildered: he's never seen her try to open it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack is at the table reading to his injured truck from AL Both are dressed in all their clothes in an effort to kee warm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For, you see, so many out-of-the- way things had happened lat-ely -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lately.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - lately, that Alice had begun to think that very few things indeed were really impossible. Ma comes to the table and doles out half-thawed green bea

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lunch!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have to use them up before they rot. Once we eat we'll feel warmer. Jack makes himself chew a limp bean. Ma nibbles a few, wi show of enthusiasm. Jack looks at his three-wheeled truck

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When's Old Nick going to put the power back?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Soon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When's soon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Once he's not mad with me anymore. Jack watches the bruises on her throat move.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope he never comes back not ever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack.   Think about it. He does, with difficulty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No Sunday Treat?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No anything. Jack tries the bean again - then spits it out quietly. Ma watches him, kisses him, forces herself to begin telling the truth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey Jack. Remember the mouse?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My friend Mouse?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know where he is right now? Jack looks all around Room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the other side of this wall. Jack stares hard at the wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What other side?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh Jack, everything has two sides.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not an octagon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, that's -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An octagon has eight. Ma holds up her hand flat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But a wall's like this. And we're on the inside, in Room, and Mouse is on the outside, see?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In Outer Space?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, in the world.   It's much closer than Outer Space. She shows him the distance with her hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't see any outside side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But if we were outside in the world, we would, we'd be looking at the other side of this wall, and Mouse lying in the grass with his Ma. We'd see trees and cars and -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grass is just TV.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it, though? You know when Door opens and the air comes in, the air that smells fresher - that's grass. Jack tries to laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't smell TV.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But it's not TV. It's the real world we smell. You're so smart, I know you've started wondering.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Jack shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where do you think Old Nick gets our food?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From TV by magic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's no magic! Everything we see on TV - it's pictures of real stuff and real people in the world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dora's real for real?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, sorry, not Dora, she's just a picture, but the other ones, with faces like ours - and there's real streets and oceans, dogs, cats -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No way. Where would they all fit?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just out there, in the world. Jack, tired of this, changes the subject.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I have a sandwich? Controlling her exasperation, Ma gets out a half slice of bread and adds a rationed scraping of peanut butter. She down his food and he comes to the table to eat it.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Ma stands with her hands in her armpits to warm them. She stares around as if for proof. Cranes up at the skylight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look! A leaf!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On skylight. She climbs up on a chair and lifts Jack onto her shoulder he can see. His head is close to the recessed skylight. H looks at a brown, sodden half-rotted leaf.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dumbo Ma. That's not a leaf. Leaves are green.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the trees they are but when they fall they rot, like salad, in the fridge, they -.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's all the stuff you said? Trees and dogs and -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, we can't see them from here because the skylight looks upwards instead of sideways. Jack suddenly struggles to get down, nearly toppling them

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're just tricking me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No I'm not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Liar liar pants on fire!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack. I couldn't explain before, you were too small to understand, so.. I had to make up a story.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But now - it's the opposite of lying, I'm unlying, because now you're five I think you can understand about the world, you have to understand. Jack shakes his head, not in bewilderment but in resistan

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to be four again. They face each other, standing with the table between the Ma musters the energy to try again, telling him her own s this time. She picks up Jack's copy of ALICE IN WONDERLAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know how Alice wasn't always in Wonderland?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She fell down down down the hole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'm like Alice. I wasn't always in Room. A heavy silence, as Jack absorbs this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I used to be a little girl called Joy. I lived-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nah!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I lived in a house out in the world (taps on the wall)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - with my mom and dad. You'd call them Grandma and Grandpa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What house?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The house where we lived, with a hammock in the back yard. We used to swing in the hammock and eat ice cream.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A TV house?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not TV, Jack. Are you listening? No answer from him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And then I was nearly grown up, I was seventeen, I was walking to school and -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where was I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still up in heaven. So this guy ran up to me, saying his -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What guy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We call him Old Nick, but I don't know his real name. He pretended his dog was sick, he seemed really -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the dog's name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There was no dog. It was just a trick to get me into his truck. Old Nick stole me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want a different story.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You need to hear this one. He put me in his garden shed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here. Room's the shed. He's the only one with the code - secret numbers to open the door. I've been locked in here for seven years. Do you understand?

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Jack's had enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This story's boring. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack, the world. You wouldn't believe how big it is. Room's only a tiny stinky piece of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Room's not stinky.   Only when you do a fart. Ma sit's down. She doesn't look at Jack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't believe in your stinky world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bitter, still not looking at him)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine. That's fine Jack. Another long miserable pause. Jack, angry and upset, watc her for a while then sits down on the floor and takes out toys from under the TV. He plays quietly. Ma looks up at the skylight. As she watches a gust of win blow the leaf away. LATER - dusk Ma and Jack are in bed, under the duvet in their clothes, shuddering with cold. Jack tries the lamp. Nothing. He fi the dents in the shade then lies back down. A terrible flatness in the air. Ma is turned away from Jack. She has been crying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Next morning, a sunny day. Jack wakes up beside Ma.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's warm again. But she pulls the pillow over her head. He knows it's one of her rare catatonic Gone days.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Later. Jack eats cereal and watches DORA (sound on very l

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where do we go next? River, Bridge, Highest Hill. Will you check my backpack for something to help us? Later. TV off. Jack creeps up to Ma and studies what he c see of her bruises, which are more purple-black today. He tries to read Ma's watch but the angle makes it hard. He plays at switching Ma on with the remote. Later. Jack plays chess (with their homemade papier mГўch set) against his truck. Later. Kicks a shrivelled red balloon to keep it in the a Later. It's turned cloudy. Jack nibbles a bagel at the ta Later.   He makes a tour of his domain, his friends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eggsnake's our longest friend and fanciest. Meltedy Spoon's the best to eat with because he's more blobbier. Labyrinth is the twistiest and she hides things so I don't know where. Toilet's the best at disappearing poo. Lamp's the brightest except when the powercut. (glances at Ma)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're the best at reading and songs and lots except if you're having a Gone Day. I'm the best at drawing and jumping and growing and nearly everything. He examines the truck's broken axle. Yanks on another whe until it snaps off. Then the last two. He twists the door off. Stuffs the truck, its parts and remote in the trash. Later, light fading. Jack lies beside Ma, longing to breastfeed. Lifts the edge of her t-shirt, but doesn't da He sits up, rests his hand on the bump of Ma's foot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Next day. Ma (apparently normal again) and Jack finish th cereal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Apple? He takes a big bite and hands it back to her. Ma bites in, winces. She reaches into her mouth and pulls a tooth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bad Tooth? Can I have it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, if you want it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A little later. Jack is watching wildlife while Ma cleans from breakfast: baby turtles emerging from shells and hea down the beach. Tying up the trash bag, she finds the truck, and realizes that Jack has destroyed it because it came from Old Nick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are turtles real? Ma's head shoots up: this is the first sign that he's starting to believe her about the world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Totally real. I had a pet turtle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crocodiles, sharks, and hungry fish are all waiting in the shallows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crocodiles and sharks -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're all real.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Curious, Jack switches channels: a 1970 BBC mini-series, SIX WIVES OF HENRY VIII.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, my lord...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (eyeing the child)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not while he plays here...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll send him away -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Real?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, they're real people playing dress-up, pretending to be people from hundreds of years ago. Jack is puzzled by that. He switches channels: TOM AND JERRY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just TV?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're getting it! He watches the slapstick violence with relish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When Old Nick comes back, I'm going to kick him in the butt. This suddenly punctures her mood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack. Ma marches over and turns off the TV, startling him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One night I stood behind the door with the lid of the toilet tank - Jack looks towards it, confused: what lid?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - it used to have a lid, it was the heaviest thing in Room. When he came in I tried to smash it down on his head. But I messed up, Jack. He shoved the door shut and grabbed me by the wrist - that's why it's sore now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We could wait till he's asleep and kill him dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes we could, but then we'd have no more food - and we wouldn't know the code, on the door, to get out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Grandma and the Grandpa could come.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They don't know where we are, Jack. Room's not on any map. His eyes slide to the blank screen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I have more TV?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack, I want you to listen to me. Jack! He looks at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're old enough now and we can't wait any longer ... Jack you are going to help me trick Old Nick like Jack in the stories is always tricking the giant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A little later, Water boils in a pot on the stove. Jack l on the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to make your face so scorching hot that Old Nick will take you to the hospital in his truck, and the minute you get there you'll tell the doctors, 'Help! Police!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can tell it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll write you a note to give them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can give them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I won't be in the hospital, I'll be here. Jack jumps up, rigid with panic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It'll be OK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He won't take us both. You'll go first, just to the hospital so you can tell the police, and then... Her conviction falters at this point, but she fakes it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then you'll come rescue me. He shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll be free. Go on hikes, see birds. Ride in cars and trains and planes. I'll teach you to swim. We'll have friends. And a dog - we'll call him Lucky. A party with a cake with candles, our friends singing. Jack thinks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe next year when I'm six. Ma's face falls. Then hardens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tonight. Jack starts shaking his head frantically.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It has to be tonight. Jack flees to the wardrobe, to shut himself in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen to me.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She stops him before he can slam the louver doors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to tell him the powercut made you so cold, you got a fever. We might not get another chance. It's a miracle he didn't come last night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm your Ma. Sometimes I have to pick for both of us. Slowly, she pulls, till his small hands release the doors

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Later. Jack is back on the bed, his face red. Ma holds a cloth wrung out with hot water over his forehead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ow!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You need to feel hot when he touches you. Jack starts crying at the prospect. Ma strokes him as she presses the bag to his forehead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crying's good, it makes you look sicker. Then she moves the bag to each cheek in turn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And stay floppy, remember? You're too weak to move or say a word.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She shoves her fingers down her throat to make her retch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing? Ma manges to vomit a little. She rubs it on the pillow beside Jack, which horrifies hi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Makes you smell sick. Ma checks her watch, and presses the cloth to his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remember when you get to the hospital you give them the note. Show me how you hold it out. Jack fumbles in his pocket for the edge of the note. Something falls out with it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that. She picks it up. Her bad tooth. She gives it back to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See, that's a bit of me you have with you all the time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm scared. Ma strokes his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The door beeps, startling them both. Ma shoves the wet rag and the pot of hot water under the Jack hides his red face in the pillow, goes limp. The door opens and Old Nick steps in with a grocery bag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There you are! He scowls at her, and shoulders the door shut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know the drill: not a peep out of you till the door's shut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, just - Jack's really bad. Old Nick puts the groceries down, grimacing at the smell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was so cold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You brought that on yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I couldn't keep him warm, and now he's burning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give him one of those painkillers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've tried, he pukes them back up. Old Nick comes up close to Jack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't - He elbows her out of the way lays his hand across Jack's forehead. Jack lets out a whimper of fear that passes for pain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll get him something stronger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's only five! Dehydrated, temperature this high, he could go into convulsions any minute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut up and let me think.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He needs antibiotics.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll bring something tomorrow night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tomorrow night? You have to take him to the ER right now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enough with the hysterics.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm begging you. Please! Old Nick taps the code into the keypad, hiding his hand. clings to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you're even halfway human - As the door opens he thrusts her away and she stumbles. When the door booms shut, Jack lifts his head. Their tric didn't work... and he's relieved. Ma is crumpled against wall where she fell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack sleeps sweetly and peacefully in Ma's arms in bed. She stares into the dark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Next morning, Jack is eating his cereal cheerfully. Ma, hollow-eyed, hasn't touched hers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So Edmond pulls his friend's body out of the bag and hides it, and he climbs into the bag, and lies super still until the guards come. Jack nods, enjoying the familiar story.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And that's what you're going to do. He stops eating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See? It's even tricksier than pretending to be sick: this time you're going to be dead. Jack looks over at the folded paper grocery bags.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with relief)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our bags are too small for being dead in. Ma shoves the table and chairs away to one side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it time for Track? Ma starts hauling up the rug, testing how it bends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rug's going to be the bag, see?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to be dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pretending to be dead, that's all. Wrapped up so Old Nick can't see that you're alive. But not floppy this time. All stiff like a robot. And not a sound. And I'll be in your head, talking to you all the time. (she taps Jack's head)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: MA (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's going to carry you outside, all rolled up in Rug, and he'll put you in the back of his pick-up and drive somewhere to bury you - JACK (OVERLAPPING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! MA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's OK. You'll wriggle free and jump out of the truck. You'll - JACK (OVERLAPPING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't like this trick. MA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Jack, let's try rolling you up. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh uh. MA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please Jack, try just for a minute. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Half a minute. MA

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: A little later: He's lying down on the rug.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okey-dokey. She rolls him up. We're with Jack inside the rug.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you hear me? Can you breathe?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excellent! He'll pick you up - stay stiff as you can. Jack holds himself rigid as Ma lifts him up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then he'll put you in his truck. Set down awkwardly, Jack bites his lip, but stays quiet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The second you hear the engine - She makes engine noises and shakes him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - that means Old Nick's busy driving, so that's your chance to start wriggling out. Now, Jack. Wriggle out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't.   I'm stuck. He bursts into loud tears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remember your superpowers. Jack cries harder. Ma unrolls him fast and hugs him. Then takes a long breath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ok, it's too many turns. Up, up. I'll fold the end over like this. (She folds the end of the rug to make it narrower)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now lie down and fold your arms like this.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She folds them across Jack's chest, elbows sticking out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There, Now push up your arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Push, Jack. His elbows scrape through and his fingers clasp hers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now roll. Jack makes a feeble try, barely moves. Pants, sobs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OK. Take a breath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get me out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're getting yourself out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Out!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you panic, Old Nick will hear that you're alive, and he'll be mad. Jack groans.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know you, Jack. I know you can do this. Jack clenches his teeth and starts to writhe and roll sid side. He rolls over face down, and gets his butt slightly in th air, bending the cylinder of the rug. He rolls the other way, sits up: the rug opens. He claws way out, his face red and smeared. Ma is looking almost a distraught as him, but she grins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You did it! You're the banana!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hate you. The first time he's ever said it: they're both shocked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's OK. I brought you here to Room. I didn't mean to but I did, and I've always been so glad. And now it's my job to get you out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Later. Jack's lying half rolled in the rug. He's been wai for hours. Ma crouches beside him drilling him in the pla

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truck, wriggle out, Jump, Run -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait till the truck slows down at the first stop sign - if you jump when it's going fast you might - She stops talking so as not to cry. Checks her watch. Sta at the door as if she can will it to open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So Truck, Wriggle Out, Jump when it Slows Down... Jack struggles to remember the list.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somebody, Run -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jump, Run, then shout to Somebody and show them the Note. Jack checks the for note in his pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell them your Ma is Joy Newsome and В­

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who is Somebody?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anybody - the first person you see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An actual real person. Ma nods, worried by his lingering confusion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What if Old Nick unwraps me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's not going to - Ma falters, puts her head in her hands. She collects hers

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got Bad Tooth in your pocket? Jack points to his cheek.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's in here so I don't lose it. Beat

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're going to love it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The world. Living in the hammock house with your Grandma and Grandpa...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you. We see that Ma doesn't believe she'll get out, but she no Bends over and hides her face by putting it against his.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sing. Ma kneels back up into position.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One evening as the sun went down and the jungle fire was burning, down the track came a hobo hikin', and he said "Boys, I'm not turning. I'm headed for a land that's far away, beside the crystal fountains. So, come with me, we'll go and see the Big - The door beeps, and Ma rolls Jack up, very fast. We're in dark with him, the rug pressing close. Sound of Old Nick stepping in. Proud of himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Antibiotics. The door shuts with a boom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you nuts, wrapping a sick kid up in that? Ma's voice is very close because she's bent over the rug.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He got worse in the night. She waits, giving Old Nick time to figure it out. In the rug, Jack lies frozen except for his flickering ey

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He wouldn't wake up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you sure? She lets seven years of rage pour out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Am I sure? In the rug, Jack blinks in fright.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah gee.   That's - Poor girl. His self-justification kicks in right away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guess it must have been serious, pills wouldn't have worked anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You killed my baby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take it easy. Let me - Jack's eyes squeeze tightly shut: total darkness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keep your hands off him!

dialogues.speaker: OK, OK.
dialogues.text: Jack opens his eyes again, inside the rug.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He can't stay here, you know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where will you take him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. I'm thinking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not here. I'd feel him. I'd know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drive him somewhere nice, somewhere with lots of trees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trees, sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keep him wrapped up. Swear you won't even look at him with your filthy eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I swear. (thinks)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It'll be dark in an hour.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (screams at him)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now. I can't bear it.

dialogues.speaker: OK, OK.
dialogues.text: Jack feels himself being scooped up by Old Nick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gently!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get back and turn around. Jack is tilted head down as Old Nick taps the code. Ma st to moan quietly. A swaying motion as he carries Jack outs Ma's voice is cut off by the boom of the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're with Jack; glimpses of twilight sky, shrubs, hedge through the end of the carpet. A terrible pause as Old Nick contemplates the back yard. walks on. Jack is heaved face-down into the flatbed of an pick-up. A pause - Jack senses a light going on nearby. Then the c of a shovel being dropped onto the bed of truck beside th rug. Old Nick's footsteps, heading for the driver's seat. Soun the truck rumbling to life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sound and shaking: the truck roars along too fast. We're with Jack, stunned, face-down in the darkness.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: At last he remembers that he's meant to be wriggling out. He writhes, but the rug has tightened in transit. With an effort, Jack manages to roll over. No better. The engine quietens as the truck slows. Jack is not sure that's his signal and anyway he's still trapped in the ru The truck doesn't stop at the stop sign, only slows. Jack remembers his arm. He forces it above his head, winc as the rug scrapes the skin off his elbow. Jack puts all misery into movement, thrashing about, kicking, jack-knif like a dying fish. The truck's engine lulls as it makes a rolling stop. Jack feels the rug slide a little across the flatbed, whi gives him just enough momentum that he bends, with a deep grunt, and the rug starts to roll open. He bursts out, on hands and knees: like a birth. Elbow an lip bloody, face covered in hair, snot and tears. The world hits Jack: street lamps, wind in his face, shoc colors of the sunset. Trees and houses looming and then receding, like a rollercoaster. His glance falls on the shovel meant for his grave. Jack's eyes focus on the cab of the truck and what he realizes must be the back of Old Nick's head, driving. Old Nick slows at the third stop, and swings right. Jack flung headlong, banging his leg on the left of the flatbe The truck screeches to a stop, because Old Nick heard the noise and glimpsed Jack in his rearview mirror. He flings the driver's door open. Jack scrabbles over to the opposite side. Old Nick jumps down and strides around the truck. Jack leaps down to the tarmac, bloodying his left knee. H jaw smashes into his right knee. He picks a direction at random and tears away from the truck, stumbles, keeps goi A large dog on a long leash, emerges from a yard.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: DOUG(a big man in his forties) and his 2-year-old daughte CARRIE, both in winter outdoor clothes, follow. Jack runs into the man, finds himself on the ground with dog snarling at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boomer! He pulls the dog away by the collar. Old Nick catches up, and scoops Jack up with one arm. Pinned in the air, Jack lashes out in soundless terror. O Nick strides back towards the truck with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me? Hey. Old Nick puts Jack down but holds his shoulders. Jack cringes, eyes on the ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm so sorry. Is your little girl

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's under control. Doug stares at Jack's bloody knee, elbow, lip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She been in some kind of accident? You want me to call someone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll take care of it. Jack can't speak, but pulls out the note. Old Nick snatch it out of his hand, scrunching it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that you got there, honey?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you mind your own business and I'll mind mine?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OK, I don't like this.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He pulls out his cellphone and dials. Old Nick picks up J again and hurries to his truck. Doug waits impatiently for the emergency operator.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouts after Old Nick)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got your plates, mister! K93 - Old Nick drops Jack in the street and breaks into a run.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey! Hey! Jack, lying in a heap, hears the driver's door slam. Then the engine starts. Jack looks around: the truck is barrelling towards him. Confused and dizzy, he crawls tow the sidewalk. The truck roars past: a getaway, not attemp murder. Jack watches the truck zoom through the next stop. He collapses and blinks up at the vast evening sky. After beat, Doug, leaning in, interrupts the view. The dog is there, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's OK, Honey. Jack curls himself up in a ball.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A patrol car pulls up at the scene. Doug leaves the still curled up Jack and hurries to the car to talk to the emer OFFICER GRABOWSKI. Jack, shuddering with cold notices Carrie staring at him. He feels his lip, touches the blood, looks at it, tastes. Then sees an oval on the ground. He picks it up: a leaf. OFFICER PARKER, a female officer, hunkers down beside him

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey there, I'm Officer Parker. What's your name? There's something reassuring about her and Jack forces himself to talk to one of these alien beings - but barely whispering, and he can't look her in the eye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack. She leans in to hear him better. Jack flinches away. Officer Grabowski comes closer now, on his walkie-talkie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have a disturbed female juvenile, possible domestic -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Male. He does a double-take.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Correction, male juvenile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must be freezing, Jack. With a jerk of the head, she sends Grabowski to the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on the walkie-talkie)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's negative. White male, six feet, forties, fifties, beard, red pick-up, Ford, nineties F150, maybe, no state partial plate K93.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you have another name? Jack? He jumps, not realizing she was talking to him again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know how old you are? Jack nods. Peeks at her buckle, badge, gun, not face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How many fingers?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nonplussed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ten.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (incredulous)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're ten years old?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ten fingers. He spreads his two hands. He still can't meet her eye but he's desperately trying to communicate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I meant show me with your fingers how old you are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm five. He spreads one hand, in case she doesn't get it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Five, great. And your address? Jack doesn't know what this means, so ignores it. Back wi blanket, Officer Grabowski addresses Parker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guess we should get onto Child Protection? She makes a 'wait' gesture and wraps the blanket around J who stiffens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where do you sleep at night, Jack? Where do you go to bed?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In Wardrobe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a wardrobe?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have a Mom, Jack?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ma.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that her real name, Jack?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She used to be Joy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is there another name, after Joy. Jack struggles but can't remember `Newsome'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's your Mom right now? Jack suddenly realizes that Old Nick - furious because Ja alive and has escaped - might be heading back to hurt her

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What room? Where's the room?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not on any map. Officer Parker's questions come faster as her concern gro

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The man with the truck, that your dad? Ma's boyfriend? You know him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Old Nick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Speak up! Officer Parker glares at him: he's not helping.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (louder)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Old Nick. But that's not his name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did this Nick guy hurt you? She goes to touch his lip, but he flinches away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I bit me by accident. And the, the, the - He pats the ground to remember the word.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hard of the street. I jumped and smasheded my knee.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He remembers Bad Tooth and takes it out of his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that, Jack?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bit of Ma. Both officers peer at Bad Tooth, and exchange a dark look

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inside the moving police car. Jack's head jerks as he tri to make sense of the passing images. He flinches as a car passes in the other direction. Bewildering signs: YIELD, HIDDEN DRIVEWAY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, Jack? You see anything?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, but anything you recognise? Your room, Jack, is it in a bungalow - all one level? Or stairs? What's outside the room?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Space. (corrects himself) The world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He plucks at the seat belt, which is too high for him and pressing uncomfortably on his neck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You reckon the kid's on something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack, when you step out the door -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack shakes his head anxiously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't like to go outside?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We don't know to open the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My money's on some kind of cult. The tooth, the long hair...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is there daylight in your room?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How many windows?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zero.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He makes a circle with his finger so she'll understand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then how does the sun come in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through Skylight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excellent. (on her walkie-talkie)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Check the satellite. Sounds like his mother's being held in a house with a skylight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Needle in a haystack...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Room's not a house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Might get more out of him when he's had some sleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Grabowski)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom, give me a break.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (overlapping)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Room's a... a shed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A shed! You're doing great, Jack. Now, after you got in the truck - Jack shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He putted me - I wasn't meant to be alive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What made you jump out of the truck, Jack?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ma said in my head. He taps it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did she say, exactly?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jump when it Slows Down. But I couldn't, I was all... He's remembering being trapped in the rug.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what did you do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The third time, I got banged.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The third time of what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The third slow, everything went sideways - (mimes being flung across flatbed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - and then it stopped and I jumped and -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gotcha! She closes her eyes and fixes the geometry of Jack's jour in her mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on her walkie-talkie)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Control. Listen carefully. South on Maple, three stop signs from the junction with Beach, look for a garden shed with a skylight. Officer Grabowski, impressed, swings the car around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Minutes later. Outside an unlit house, with a Police van a back-up, unmarked car parked facing the other way. A pl clothes OFFICER is knocking on the front door of the hous Jack watches through the car window as Officer Parker consults with an OLDER WHITE MALE OFFICER, also plain clothes. Parker and the older officer start to poke aroun the side of the house, disappearing for a moment before running back. Officer Parker takes what looks like a crow from the trunk of the car. She draws her weapon. Grabowsk moves to leave the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stay with the boy. She disappears around the back of the house. Jack hyperventilates, thinking about Old Nick and Ma.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (eyes Jack in mirror)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You OK, kid? We hear shouting, a crack of splitting wood. Jack starts clawing at the car door, can't find the handle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, hey, take it easy. A figure hurtles towards the car: Ma. She can't get the d open either because of the lock. Faces pressed to the glass, she and Jack almost touch. Th at last the door is open and Jack is in her arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A little later. Jack and Ma, in blankets, hold each other the police cruiser moves through the night. Jack does a huge yawn, utterly exhausted now the adrenali gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can we go to Bed now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can do anything. They'll find us somewhere to sleep soon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, but Bed. In Room.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Ma realizes he thought their escape would be temporary. S hugs him as he drifts off to sleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still in Ma's arms, Jack half wakes to find himself carri through a hospital emergency room. They are being bustled along by Officers Parker and Grabowski, A FEMALE PLAIN CLOTHES DETECTIVE, a DOCTOR, a NURSE and a HOSPITAL SECUR GUARD. A woman in her 50s, is beside them, her arm around This is NANCY, Ma's mother. It's like a strange dream to Jack. Through the group around him he can make out other figures waiting in chairs. He can hear a drunk shouting, phones ringing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ma. Ma shushes him, stroking his hair. He drifts back to slee

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Next morning. A bright hospital room. Jack and Ma share t fancy hospital bed. A cot bed, unused, has been set up to side. Jack is awake but content to lie close to Ma for a while - studying the dials and switches on the wall above head. He looks at Ma, asleep, bruises fading to yellow-gr He sits up and pulls back the sheet. He's wearing only a of underpants from Room which look particularly wretched this new antiseptic environment. He touches the part of t mattress he's being lying on. It's damp. He examines a bandage on his knee. He gets up. On a side table, he sees plate with the remains of some toast on it and a half dru cup of tea. He sniffs at the food. There are two surgical masks there, also. He walks slowly to the opposite wall, little figure silhouetted against the translucent blinds. stops in front of the one window which has its blind draw The hospital suite is high up and the view is spectacular

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: From the back we study Jack's small figure and beyond it vast world below.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Coming around on Jack's face we see that he is trying to sense of what he's seeing. It takes him a moment to reali what he's looking at and how high above ground he is. His breathing quickens and he turns and scurries back to bed. He shakes his mom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ma. Ma. She begins to wake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning sleepy head. I was waiting so long for you to wake I fell back asleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this another planet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Same one, just a different bit. It's a room - (hears the word)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bedroom in a hospital. Jack thinks about this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are we sick for real or pretend?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're not sick. We're the opposite of sick. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long are we staying?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not long. Grandma saw us last night and she'll take us when they say we're OK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Grandpa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was away at work but he's getting on a plane to come home.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Beat. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wetted the bed ... before. I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's OK. The bedside phone bursts to life, frightening Jack. Ma pi it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, just now. OK ... if that's OK, thank you. Ma hangs up as Jack starts tugging the sheets off the bed She stops him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry about that. Someone will wash it. Come on, we have to get ready. Ma steps out of bed. She's wearing a robe. It says `Tyler Forest Hospital'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you like it? There's one for you, too. She picks up a robe from beside the bed, puts him in it - it's way too big, then she begins to take off his damp underpants.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
